title: Senior Nationals quit frontbench after defying shadow cabinet on hate speech laws | ABC NEWS
description: The Nationals senators Bridget McKenzie, Ross Cadell and Susan McDonald have quit the frontbench after opposing the Coalition's official position on hate speech laws.  In a statement Sussan Ley said the Nationals had agreed to honour cabinet solidarity, which was breached when they crossed the floor against a vote on the reforms last night. title: Greenland starts wearing their own MAGA caps | ABC NEWS
description: In a clear message to the US president, people in Greenland are wearing red caps reading "Make America Go Away".    Rattled European allies are debating how to stand up to Donald Trump after he escalated his threats to take over Greenland and pledged to punish its supporters with tariffs.   By Grace McKinnon for the ABC News Social Media Team.  To personalise your news & stay in the know, download the ABC News app through your app store. title: Dame Marie Bashir's devotion to public service as fmr governor of NSW | ABC NEWS
description: There's been an outpouring of tributes for Dame Marie Bashir, New South Wales' first female governor, who has died aged 95. She's being remembered as a pioneer in medicine, and for serving the state with signature warmth and grace. NSW Premier Chris Minns has announced a state funeral will be held in her memory. title: Coalition in crisis as all Nationals resign from shadow ministry | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The future of the Coalition is hanging in the balance after the eight remaining Nationals in the shadow ministry quit their roles in solidarity with three senior colleagues dumped for opposing new hate laws.   Senators Bridget McKenzie, Susan McDonald and Ross Cadell were dropped from the frontbench today, after they broke shadow cabinet solidarity, fuelling speculation of another Coalition split.  Nationals sources have confirmed all members of the party have resigned from the Coalition frontbench. Jane Norman reports. title: What are the post-Bondi hate laws and how did they get passed? | ABC NEWS
description: It's been a rocky, but swift, road for the government's gun and hate laws, which passed through parliament today, and the fallout continues to be felt in Canberra.  The eight remaining Nationals in shadow cabinet have quit their roles in solidarity with three colleagues dumped for opposing the new hate laws as part of the Coalition. But what will the changes mean?   By political reporter Claudia Long   ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Questions remain as Venezuela adjusts to 'new normal' | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Weeks on from the US capture of the former Venezuelan president Nicol√°s Maduro and his wife, political uncertainty remains. title: Barcelona train crash kills driver and critically injures passengers | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Emergency crews worked through the night to recover passengers aboard a commuter train that crashed near Barcelona, just two days after another train crash killed at least 41 people in Spain's south. Spain has woken to the second of three days of mourning for the first deadly crash in Adamuz as investigators and King Felipe arrived at the crash site. title: "Insidious threat" - UN criticises Russian attacks on Ukraine power grid | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The UN's human rights chief has labelled Russian attacks on civilian infrastructure in Ukraine as a cruel and clear breach of the rules of war, as temperatures there plunge below zero. Civilians are bearing the brunt, with the UN saying hundreds of thousands of families are living without heating. Emmanuelle Chaze joined The World's Girish Sawlani from Kyiv, and said the situation for people there is "dire".
